body: @gianm I use `git rebase master`, the return message is "Current branch fix-reset-bug-in-ByteBufferHashTable is up to date."

Thank you for your inquiry, but we cannot support extensions outside of `io.druid`

Unfortunately this includes `com.alibaba` I'll leave this open in the hopes that another community member can direct you to the best place to get assistance who may be more familiar with that extension.

@leventov yes, what you described would indeed be a negative cache, but currently the hybrid cache only does positive caching. It will cache L2 hits in L1, but it will not cache L2 misses in L1, so if I kept querying the hybrid cache for the same NamedKey which is neither in L1 nor L2 over and over again, then the hybrid cache would keep punching out to L2 over and over again.

I can see how one of the use-cases for the hybrid cache is that one historical can pick up entries cached by another historical (in context in-tier replication) and that a naive negative cache would conflict with that but perhaps there is a way to have both.

Okay, as it turned out, broker caching was masking a whole different issue. We had 30k+ segments which was the root cause of the slowness. We turned on `druid.coordinator.merge.on` and everything was automagically resolved.
CLA is done. Please check it.

So, we'll set 1 min(configurable of course) pooling timeout (if no-one uses that connection in a min then its removed from the pool and discarded) so that near expiry connections are not given to DirectDruidClient.

I think we need to decide on what our upgrade path strategy is going to be (see comment: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4815#discussion_r151513937). If we want to allow upgrades from pre-0.11.1 to 0.12, 0.13, 0.2, etc. arbitrarily, then we can't assume that the legacy code will go away after 0.11.1 is cut. If we are okay enforcing that users must pass through 0.11.1 on their upgrade path to support rolling updates, then that simplifies the backwards-compatibility logic since we can plan for old code to be dropped immediately. Not sure what Druid's stance is on this generally, and for this case (Kafka indexing still being marked as experimental). @gianm thoughts?
Is it expected that we have two almost identical classes called "DataSegmentTest" in different modules?

> Not sure what Druid's stance is on this generally ...

There has never been an official discussion about this. In general, we provide rolling upgrade path for at least one release. Beyond one release, they can be considered on per case basis.
In this case putting any major effort for de-duplication of legacy code doesn't look necessary and we should rather remove it before next set of any major changes made to the code or in 0.11.3 (or whatever 2nd release after 0.11.1 would be) whichever happens earlier.
I agree with Himanshu, this code should be removed in version greater than 0.11.1

> Is it expected that we have two almost identical classes called "DataSegmentTest" in different modules?

If they are testing different things and can't be merged into single class, then its fine. Or else, please merge them.

> Pruned DataSegment.loadSpec on Brokers

Can we just drop them from announcements made from historicals/realtime-processes instead ? I think @nishantmonu51 already made a change at some point to optionally drop metric/dimension names.
does this end up doing login with kerberos server on each request? if yes, wouldn't that slow down each request. else  :+1:

on a quick look , task spec ( https://pastebin.com/raw/cxFBYn7q ) looks fine to me , you don't need to include same list in ingestionSpec.dimensions . however it should have still worked as the list is same.

how did you verify that new segments still had unwanted dimensions that you did not mention in your task spec?
did the reindexing job finish successfully? from task logs can you see that it published new segments and verified that those specific segments had extra dimensions?

@himanshug The indexing job succeeded, I verified by : 
- historical `cat var/druid/segment-cache/gwiq-daily-s/.../meta.smoosh` lists all the dimensions
- also the segments got fresh timestamp as they were replaced
- some dimensions are doubled `d_d` & `d_D` and `pivot` fails on duplicate dimensions when introspecting druid's metadata, which is one of the reasons I'm doing this.

In the indexing-logs I can see : 
```
2017-11-16T07:04:06,300 INFO [task-runner-0-priority-0] io.druid.indexer.IndexGeneratorJob - Adding segment gwiq-daily-s_2017-04-05T00:00:00.000Z_2017-04-18T00:00:00.000Z_2017-11-16T05:32:04.493Z to the list of published segments
```


There are endpoints at coordinator ( https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/server/src/main/java/io/druid/server/http/MetadataResource.java ) to get source of truth details of a Segment information from DB.
So, I'm not sure if there is any benefit in keeping that information even in Coordinator memory.

In fact I would change even the default behavior to not publish dimension, metrics, loadSpecs information in announcements so that all users get that.

does anyone else have an opinion ? @gianm @drcrallen @nishantmonu51

> Not sure what Druid's stance is on this generally, and for this case (Kafka indexing still being marked as experimental).

For non-experimental features we promise that there is some way to do a rolling update from any version X to version X + N. But that way may require going through specific other versions along the way, rather than directly from X to X + N. We try to limit how often we require this in practice, however, since if we pushed the limits every time we had the opportunity, it would annoy users.

For experimental features we don't make really any promise. But Kafka indexing is a special case I think, since it's in relatively wide use for an experimental feature (just like lookups) and it would be good to be considerate of users. So we are just trying to find a good balance here between kindness to users and code maintainability.

IMO, in this case, the right balance is to cut the legacy migration code in 0.12.0.

0.12.0 is fine or 2 releases that I said before (we'll likely get to 0.12.0 in 2nd release anyway). my main point is not to spend much extra effort in trying to refactor code in any major way only for sake of removing duplication between legacy and newer code.

I think the best solution for now is polling to check the ```/test``` path exists instead of waiting for ```CuratorEventType.CREATE```using latch. I'll update this PR shortly.

I added an interface to ```Announcer``` to know for which ZK paths CHILD_ADDED events are received. This doesn't look the best way, but safest.
Do you think this is masking a real bug in the Announcer? If so what kind of bug do you suspect -- and can you leave a comment?

Well, the root cause is Zookeeper and PathChildrenCache don't guarantee that Announcer will get all events (http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/curator-user/201711.mbox/%3CCACZfFK51%2BZd3eP16bhuQZ5jfSNzQ-1bcQW3MOkFbgqiKBx4CVw%40mail.gmail.com%3E), so Announcer should be based on something another system which guarantees it. I added a comment.

it was decided in dev-sync today to go with current state of this PR wherein historicals announce the loadSpec and they are dropped by broker only.
Also please fix "unused declaration", IntelliJ inspection fails

### Changes to Kafka Indexing Service
- **Decoupling of Druid segments and Kafka partitions** - Starting with this release, number of segments created by a Kafka Indexing Task is decoupled from number of Kafka partitions that the task is consuming from. Lets say if there are 10 partitions in Kafka and 2 Kafka Indexing tasks are running then each task will consume messages from 5 partitions, earlier the tasks would create 5 segments (one segment for each partition), now the task will create a single segment for each segment granular interval; all the records from consumed partitions go to a single druid segment. 
- **Incremental hand-off** - Kafka Indexing Task now also has the ability to do incremental hand-offs which means that all the segments created by a task will not be held up till the task duration is over. As soon as `maxRowsPerSegment` limit is hit, all the segments held up by the task at that point in time will be handed-off and new set of segments will be created for further messages. This also means that now the task can run for longer durations of time without accumulating old segments locally on Middle Manager nodes. Incremental handoff is not supported with `pauseAfterRead` feature.
- **Miscellaneous bug fixes**
#### Rolling upgrade
Since Kafka Indexing Service was marked experimental, with this release, there are protocol changes between Kafka Supervisor and Kafka Indexing task and also some changes to metadata persisted on disk. Therefore, to support rolling upgrade, all the Middle Managers will need to be upgraded **first** before the Overlord. Note that this ordering is different from the standard order of upgrade, also note that this ordering is only specific to Kafka Indexing Service. If one is not using Kafka Indexing Service or can handle down time for Kafka Supervisor then one can upgrade in any order.

Until the point in time Overlord is upgraded, all the Kafka Indexing Task will behave in same manner (even if they are upgraded) as earlier which means no decoupling and incremental hand-offs. Once, Overlord is upgraded, the new tasks started by the upgraded Overlord will support the new features.

#### Roll back
Depending on how roll-back is done, in worst case, current set of tasks will fail. Once, both Overlord and Middle Managers are upgraded, new set of tasks should be started by Supervisor which would continue to work. Better to roll back Overlord first and then Middle Managers. Note of caution - Rolling back is not tested.

@hamlet-lee thanks, i have resolved that. After  i set timeZone of  **segmentGranularity** in supervisor-spec.json, it works fine.
I only found this out because we are using arrays in avro payloads serialized by tranquility through the Avro druid-avro-extensions.
